text: what is the most awesome place in the
world seems like that would be pretty
much the most subjective question ever
but this week scientists used a set of
objective criteria to come up with a
list of the world's most biologically
important places there might be one near
you I'm Hank green and this is scishow
news it's official
Dave's basement is not an important
place at least as far as ecologists are
concerned as described in Thursday's
edition of the journal Science a team of
researchers led by the center for
functional and evolutionary ecology put
together a list of the most biologically
irreplaceable places on earth which
seems like a tough call because the
world is a diverse place right well
working through a list of almost 200,000
areas known for their biological
importance the researchers ranked each
one based on its importance to rare and
threatened species they calculated the
fraction of every species on the IUCN
Red List that's the official list of the
world's threatened and endangered
species that lived in each place and
then gauged how dependent each species
was on that particular area they ended
up with 137 sites that were deemed the
most irreplaceable and while I wish we
had time to talk about all 137 of them
together a sample of only four might be
enough to give you a sense of how
amazing mind-blowing beautiful the
diversity of life is that's hiding out
there let's start with the exhumed WA
Mountains National Park in Tanzania this
isolated mountain park contains a whole
Earth's worth of habitats in one place
tropical rain forests woodlands
grasslands and steppes
it's home to more than 400 bird species
and six primate species five of which
can only be found there for example the
highly endangered Sanjay mangabey
monkeys that have been vulnerable to
poaching because they live mostly on the
ground and there's the extremely weird
grey faced sangee an elephant shrew that
was only discovered in 2008 and most of
which live entirely inside the park
while Otunga is rich in threatened
mammals it's got nothing on number three
the palawan game refuge in the
Philippines composed of Island mangroves
and grasslands palawan has the greatest
mammal diversity of any site on the list
but it's most famous for its birds
twelve species of which are endemic
including the beautiful palawan peacock
pheasant despite the parks small size
only 7600 square kilometers it's home to
more than 200 bird species and sick
hundred butterfly species thankfully
since it's isolated on a chain of
islands palawan has been well preserved
number two on our list is more
endangered though due to grazing and
plantations encroaching upon it the
Western gouts in western India are the
last hope for animals like the
lion-tailed macaque which lives in the
region's dwindling rainforests and with
competition from domestic livestock in
the spread of invasive plants fewer than
2000 nilgiri tahr a rather lovely kind
of ibex survived Western gouts is also
full of endangered frogs like this
species which was only discovered in
2001 but if you're really looking for a
Daedric species you have to head to
number one kana aneema National Park in
Venezuela
ranked as the most irreplaceable site
for overall animal diversity in the
world
Ghana EEMA owes its one-of-a-kind
biodiversity to an equally unique
geological feature steep flat topped
mountains in the park called tip Wiis
they've managed to isolate its many
different habitats for thousands of
years thousands of metres above the
valley floor as a result each tip we is
a unique evolutionary microcosm many are
home to species found nowhere else like
the Roraima black fraud restricted to
the summit of only two mountaintops in
the world although the frog is well
protected for now it's tiny range makes
it vulnerable to pretty much any
disturbance which is like the whole
point of the list having identified the
most irreplaceable places the
researchers are calling for more
protection of these sites I think that
we've all got a special place in our
hearts that we want to see preserved or
that maybe we wish had been preserved
and that'd be a cool thing to talk about
